article.headline: This investor just inherited 7,000 shares of Apple â and the internet has advice on what he should do now
article.body: To hold, or not to hold? Thatâs the question from a guy who just learned that his recently deceased grandfather left him 7,000 shares of Apple AAPL, +1.74%. This personâs grandfather put money earmarked for college into Apple in 2003 when the Reddit poster enlisted in the military, he stated in a thread on that forum. The person told Reddit users about his windfall on Tuesday, a day before Appleâs market capitalization crossed the $2 trillion milestone on an intraday basis. Assuming the stock stayed at its midday trading levels around $467.50, the man with 7,000 shares is looking at a $3.27 million stake in the iPhone and Mac maker. In fact, if he doesnât do anything until at least the end of the month, heâll have 28,000 shares of the tech behemoth. Apple is undertaking a four-for-one stock split, but experts are quick to note such a split has no bearing on the companyâs value. In other words, this guy will still have $3.27 million if Wednesdayâs midday price sticks. âWhat I need to know is should I move it around or keep it rolling all in AAPL?â the poster, whose screen name is âBig-Weed,â said. Fellow Reddit users chimed in with three forms of advice: hold; diversify; and run far, far away from the online forum and find a professional to help out. One user said the man shouldnât do a thing, because that positions him alongside the likes of Warren Buffett. The Oracle of Omahaâs Berkshire Hathaway Inc. BRK.B, +0.24% BRK.A, +0.06% held 245,155,566 shares of Apple as of late March, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. âThat grandpa is world famous well known investor holding it strong, where is the risk? â¦ This is a hold for life stock,â said the user, âAlgoWinner.â Another user said the man should get ready to sell most of the holding after the stock splits and thereâs a sugar rush of highs from even more Apple shares hitting the market. Donât miss:âA tale told by an idiotâ â CNBCâs Jim Cramer urges investors not to be fooled by new highs in the stock market After those transactions, this user, âace425,â said the original poster should get âa paid off house and lock the rest of those in low risk diversified investments. â¦ Donât touch or risk your core capital and you will enjoy a lifetime of that sweet American pie so many of us can only dream of feasting on.â MarketWatch checked in with some pros for their take. The Reddit userâs first mistake was even letting people know heâs come into big-time money, according to Kashif Ahmed, president of American Private Wealth, a financial advisory firm in Bedford, Mass. âIf all of the sudden you become rich, you all of the sudden have 48 cousins,â Ahmed said. He tells clients and potential clients to clam up about windfalls, he said. Beyond those street smarts, thereâs some tax know-how to consider. Because of the âstep-up in basisâ under current estate-tax rules, an assetâs value resets for capital-gains-tax purposes upon inheritance. Suppose another grandpa bought a stock at $5 per share. Then his grandson inherited it at $10 per share and sold it at $12 per share. The rule means the tax kicks in on the profit from a sale at $10, not $5, per share. So if this man is going to unload Apple stock and diversify his investments, Ahmed said, he should act fast with a climbing stock price in order to minimize a tax bill. By the way, Ahmed added, this guy should be selling and diversifying. âIf I was him, Iâd sell the whole thing, immediately go back and buy [exchange-traded funds] that are broad-market or tech-focused,â Ahmed said. That move diversifies the manâs holdings, while retaining exposure to Apple, he said. âNothing is forever. â¦ The day of reckoning will come for all stocks,â he said. Apple shares are up 59% so far in 2020. In that same time frame, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% Â is down nearly 2.5% and the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â is up approximately 5%.
